records.text: So, cars drive on the left in the UK. Does that mean everything is flipped from the States? Well, mostly. The tube is definitely right to left. People are asked to climb the left set of stairs. In general people on the sidewalks will pass on the left. But people wait on escalators to the right. And sometimes people just walk wherever, of course.

records.text: Going to have to take tomorrow off. I’m exhausted. And the Royal Mail, when given a next-day delivery package of something kind of useful (more than a single pair of sweaty shorts), has decided that 3 days in transit is absolutely fine. I’m livid where I’m not exhausted. The Roman Baths are a good example of something that was “preserved” by being rebuilt altogether. Interesting place. Hard to know what’s real though and what’s only ghosts and 21st century make believe.

I forget that Seattle is ridiculously casual compared to the rest of the world. I hate to be an American but I’ve taken refuge in the Starbucks.

records.text: On the matter of food. I am awash in local restaurants with Yelp ratings in the low 3s. It’s almost like I got a hotel in a tourist trap. This is going to make life tricky, as I would prefer to eat, you know, good food. My choices are Italian, Middle Eastern (no thanks), maybe Indian, or British. I had a lovely pub meat pie yesterday, and am going for Italian today. But I may have to fall back on delivery if I keep exhausting my legs and not wanting to move in the evening.

records.text: So my sleep troubles have carried over into this time zone. I hope that tiredness won’t slow me down too much, I have a trip to enjoy. There are 3 separate disconnected Paddington tube stations. One of them seems to be closed, which sent me on quite the walk. London is full of fall and trip hazards compared to home. Stairs and drops happen without warning, and that’s before minding the gap (which is elevated in some spaces). No pictures yet, visiting the Shard shortly.

records.text: I read somewhere that the American West coasters are nice, but not kind and that East coasters are kind, but not nice. It’s stuck with me. I wonder what Londoners are. It’s very warm this week. Low 80s even in the clouds. Humid. Reminds me of Houston actually. Not the best conditions for walking or keeping dry clothes. I’m already soaked.And I forgot to pack a second set of shorts, so I had to order some. The human areas are small but Hyde Park is expansive.

records.text: Overheard people while I was looking at stuff in Barnes & noble. One said something like "I hate poetry because if you get it wrong you feel so dumb."That made me feel pretty sad. The US school system gives people this awful impression of poetry. When I started getting into it I approached every poem as a complex puzzle to be solved. Truth is, most poems aren't like that. They're not boxes you have to beat or oblique IQ tests. Most poems are exactly what they seem like on a few reads or so.

records.text: On the matter of food. I am awash in local restaurants with Yelp ratings in the low 3s. It’s almost like I got a hotel in a tourist trap. This is going to make life tricky, as I would prefer to eat, you know, good food. My choices are Italian, Middle Eastern (no thanks), maybe Indian, or British. I had a lovely pub meat pie yesterday, and am going for Italian today. But I may have to fall back on delivery if I keep exhausting my legs and not wanting to move in the evening.

records.text: I read somewhere that the American West coasters are nice, but not kind and that East coasters are kind, but not nice. It’s stuck with me. I wonder what Londoners are. It’s very warm this week. Low 80s even in the clouds. Humid. Reminds me of Houston actually. Not the best conditions for walking or keeping dry clothes. I’m already soaked.And I forgot to pack a second set of shorts, so I had to order some. The human areas are small but Hyde Park is expansive.

records.text: Overheard people while I was looking at stuff in Barnes & noble. One said something like "I hate poetry because if you get it wrong you feel so dumb."That made me feel pretty sad. The US school system gives people this awful impression of poetry. When I started getting into it I approached every poem as a complex puzzle to be solved. Truth is, most poems aren't like that. They're not boxes you have to beat or oblique IQ tests. Most poems are exactly what they seem like on a few reads or so.

And sometimes people just walk wherever, of course.

Hard to know what’s real though and what’s only ghosts and 21st century make believe.

records.text: Overheard people while I was looking at stuff in Barnes & noble. One said something like "I hate poetry because if you get it wrong you feel so dumb."That made me feel pretty sad. The US school system gives people this awful impression of poetry. When I started getting into it I approached every poem as a complex puzzle to be solved. Truth is, most poems aren't like that. They're not boxes you have to beat or oblique IQ tests. Most poems are exactly what they seem like on a few reads or so.

records.text: Overheard people while I was looking at stuff in Barnes & noble. One said something like "I hate poetry because if you get it wrong you feel so dumb."That made me feel pretty sad. The US school system gives people this awful impression of poetry. When I started getting into it I approached every poem as a complex puzzle to be solved. Truth is, most poems aren't like that. They're not boxes you have to beat or oblique IQ tests. Most poems are exactly what they seem like on a few reads or so.
